Gameshark vs CD
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 2 Archive (PSOne): Game Shark Codes & Dex Drive Saves: Gameshark vs CD
By Trainerly on Friday, September 21, 2012 - 11:54 am:

My investigation first started when I saw people saying that sharking a monster is not the same as doing the actual CD.

Now, maybe I am wrong but so far using 2 theories
said by Lisa and Dark Phoenix I have found the CD
and sharked version to be the same.

1. Lisa stated in a post that sharking a monster
only changes its appearance while keeping the
previous monsters guts, stat gains, and stat
multipliers the same. While this is true if the
code is used on a preexisting monster, I believe
it is not true if used when you do not have a
monster out and you go to the shrine and insert
any CD of your choice. To test it, I simply got a
mocchi straight off the MR2 disc and froze it and
saved with no monster out. I then turned on the
monster editor code to a Serenity (Pixie/Plant).
Once again I went to the shrine and just kept the
MR2 disc in and obviously got a Serenity from it.
I immediately froze her, saved, then went to Vs.
mode. At first glance it was obvious that
Serenity's guts regain was far faster than mocchis
and got to 99 long before mocchi's did. This
disproves the theory that all the technicalities
of the monster will remain the same as the
original monster.(Granted you must use the code
when getting the monster off a CD, not on a frozen
monster or one already on the farm.)

2. Dark Phoenix's theory on combining (which has
never failed me) was the second tested theory on
CD vs. sharking monsters. First, I found mocchis
multipliers 3,3,3,4,4,4. Keeping these in mind I
looked for 2 monsters with multipliers that were
pretty different from mocchis. I already had a
trained zuum in my freezer so I used him. Using
the shark code for a Jell/Golem, I made one using
the MR2 disc again. Now if the sharked Jell
stat multipliers were not the same as the
original Jell's straight off a CD that would
normally produce him and were identical to that of
the Mocchi that one would normally get off the MR2
disc I sharked, then once I fixed Jell's stats to
match zuum's stats the combination would not be
great. However, once fixing Jells stats to fix
Zuum's stats:
Zuum
Life - 201(3) x1 = 201
Power - 600(3) x1 = 600
Int - 630(2) x0.5 = 315
Ski - 999(4) x1.5 = 999
Spd - 304(3) x1 = 304
Def - 100(3) x1 = 100

Jell
Life - 201(3) x1 = 201
Power- 600(3) x1 = 600
Int - 210(4) x1.5 = 315
Ski- 999(3) x1 = 999
Spd- 608(2) x0.5 = 304
Def - 67(4) x1.5 = 101
*Keep in mind the stats don't have to be EXACTLY
the same. Just the same level.

Dadge told me I had a great combination. So far
it's holding up. So, to make sure it wasn't
mocchi's multipliers that Jell/Golem used we kept
the same stats that Jell/Golem had, and combined
Zuum and Mocchi.

Mocchi
Life - 201(3) x1 = 201
Power - 600(3) x1 = 600
Int - 210(3) x1 = 210
Ski - 999(4) x1.5 = 999
Spd - 608(4) x1.5 = 912
Def - 67(4) x1.5 = 101

NO SIR! Dadge did not tell me I had a great
combination.

So, as you can see, the sharked Jell/Golem has the
same stat multipliers as the one you would
actually find on the CD that produces him. And as
for technicalities such as guts, the sharked
Serenity was clearly faster than the mocchi that
would have been produced if not for the sharking.

So in conclusion, from my experiments, yes it is
possible to get the ACTUAL monster you want by
sharking, and not a monster that looks like the
one your sharking but actually has different
stats. You do not need to buy the CDs or make them
with a program, you can simply shark them.

If anyone has already proven this here on the site
I apologize for restating it.

If anyone has any other questions regarding
anything in the game, please ask and I will try to
test them out, whether it requires sharking or
not. I am here to help!

PS - I will try to start making a MR2 video series
on youtube that shows the various training methods
listed on this site so you can have a visual on
how to do them.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, September 22, 2012 - 12:08 am:

That looks pretty good, actually. I think where things get weird is when people try to make the types that don't really exist in the game, like a few of the opponents in-game appear to be of subs that don't exist for that monster main type.

By Trainerly on Saturday, September 22, 2012 - 07:37 am:

Thanks so much Lisa, I am happy to provide information to
give us all a better understanding of things.

Also, I am thinking about testing enemies in order to see if
they have their own stats or if they are merely another breed
with a different look.

Finally, I do imagine that when people mess around with
monsters that don't actually exist that things would get weird.
So I am not very concerned with those monsters, just real
ones.

If you feel that this is valid proof and you would like to move it
into a more "accepted info about the game" section, please do.
This is the only place I could post at, so that's why it's here.
